When the fabric of space rips apart, its zero point energy will be repotentialized, and the energy will be released to the tune of 10^95 ergs per cubic centimeter. 10^95 ergs is the energy output of 100,000,000 suns over 100,000,000 years. One cubic centimeter is about the size of a sugar cube, and space is very big. Most of that energy will be dissipated into n-dimensional space. Only a tiny fraction of it will actually enter 3-dimensional space. When the light from the rip reaches the earth, it will be brighter than the sun and if you're outside when the light from the rip becomes visible, in under one minute, fully dressed, you will be badly sunburned through your clothing. Humans will cry out to the mountains, "Fall on us and hide us, because the anger of God is upon us, and we can't stand it!" A thousand or so years later the destruction itself will reach the Earth, and in 1/1,000,000,000,000 of a second the Earth and all space around it will be annihilated. The heavens will be thrown out like a worn-out garment, and no place will they be found. If space itself ceases to exist, there will be no place at all for anything.

A paper by Sidney Coleman and Frank de Luccia apparently determined some things that they could determine about the new conditions inside the new spacetime after vacuum decay. And they determined that not only would life be impossible, but that it would immediately gravitationally collapse inside the new space. Essentially it would be like the inside of a black hole. This is their conclusion: "The possibility that we are living in a false vacuum has never been a cheering one to contemplate. Vacuum decay is the ultimate ecological catastrophe; in the new vacuum there are new constants of nature; after vacuum decay, not only is life as we know it impossible, so is chemistry as we know it. However, one could always draw stoic comfort from the possibility that perhaps in the course of time the new vacuum would sustain, if not life as we know it, at least some structures capable of knowing joy. This possibility has now been eliminated. "

Absolutely no one:
Kurzgesagt: How to destroy universe?
What if WE'RE in the vacuum decay

Usually a metastable state takes place in systems in contact with each other, with the original state not decaying usually because some symmetry rule can't be fulfilled. So what is the OTHER system outside of the degrees of freedom of the Universe? Wouldn't those degrees of freedom, by definition, be part of our description already? States only decay if there is a mechanism to "lose" energy with many more degrees of freedom - like it happens with friction, open quantum systems, etc.

Energy would otherwise only be conserved, so states wouldn't decay, while they would not be stationary (which is also arguably different from what we witness under the premises of an existent false vacuum).


I'd also like to point out 2 other possibilities and an additional thought:
- maybe the barrier for tunnelling is too damn big in length;
- maybe the barrier is too high (or higher than the total amount of energy in the universe by orders of magnetude, which would mean it is actually stable as far as we are concerned).
- if false vacuum was a thing that could be triggered by a decay in a field... Wouldn't that have happened already? I mean... There's a lot of stuff going on in the universe with very high energies. If all we'd need is a particle with enough energy to trigger or nucleate the false vacuum decay, I'd say this would likely have taken place in the universe already.

Something that kind of irks me about these Doom and Gloom scenarios: while I enjoy most of these videos, none of them seem to take into account the possibility of our understanding advancing to the point where we can even manipulate these events. Take another video, the one about heat death. No stars will be left in the Galaxy, because they have all died, read that as used up all of their energy and gone either Nova or dwarf. There is a possibility, albeit remote, that in the case of Celestial mortality becoming a major crisis, we humans could possibly have evolved our understanding enough by that point to create new stars. It is chemistry, although likely above the level we would consider to be quantum chemistry. Not impossible, however. The thirst for understanding and information is unquenchable in the case of the human mind. As a philosopher, I could see Humanity at least attempting an endeavor in which we create our own star to support life among the cosmos.

While we know there is a term limitation on our current level of Technology, we have no idea where the next evolution we'll come from. It is wholly possible that, assuming we do ever escape this planet swimming around in this particular pond, to make a discovery that will advance our technology to the point that current technology is advanced to us in the future as the first rotary phone is to us today.

@Kurzgesagt - In a Nutshell This is obviously very late, but the physics of the rolling ball (before the explanation of the Higgs Boson's potential of quantum tunneling) is not exactly correct. I indeed understand what you were doing to help explain the scenario in question, but in general kinematics, while the ball loses potential energy, it gains kinetic energy as a result, which at the bottom of the hill would be the same as the original amount of potential energy. That, of course, would be the case if you ignore friction, but even so, potential energy would be nonexistent at the bottom of that hill, rise as the ball starts up the other side of the valley, & fluctuate like that back and forth in the valley until friction brings it to the eventual resting "ground state."
In summary, I just feel like the graphic could have been more accurately done regarding the level of potential energy. Still a wonderful, well researched & carefully made video in by any means.

If vacuum decay equals Higgs field decay, wouldn't that mean that everything would become massless and therefore would move at the speed of light, like photons and (hypothetical) gravitons? That doesn't depend on the actual speed of light in the post-apocalyptic universe which might differ considerably from our current one.

Thus, no matter which kind of particles would form in a vacuum-stable universe, it would be radiation-only and virtually non-interacting. Also, the time-space geometry would be virtually flat, because there would be no mass bending it gravitationally. (I know that energy concentration theoretically also exerts gravitational force, but as everything moves at the speed of light, there is no concentration of anything.) And because anything moving at light speed doesn't feel time, the vacuum-stable universe would be timeless for all practical purposes. All in all, a quite boring place. (But, hey, godspeed!)

So, although we don't know much about that strange space after the final bang, we actually can predict some of its characteristics.

You know, for a while I did actually become horribly paranoid at the thought that the entire Earth could disappear in the fraction of a second, with no warning and no way to stop it. Then I remembered something important:

To our knowledge, the universe is 13 billion years old. Genetic engineering MIGHT extend our life for hundreds or even thousands of years, but for the sake of argument let us simply assume each of us will die in a hundred years. A hundred years is roughly one hundredth of a millionth of the time we believe the universe has existed. The fact that it hasn't happened yet doesn't guarantee anything for the future, but it at least gives me the (possibly false) confidence that if it does happen, it will not occur in our lifetimes, and I hope that if you did take the time to read this comment then any worry of yours for your own safety might be alleviated.

Just to clarify, it's technically inaccurate to say all things tend towards their ground state. For example, an electron in an excited state will remain in that state indefinitely. The only reason we observe spontaneous decay is due to fluctuations in the vacuum field that can produce photons. If this vacuum field did not exist, the excited state would remain and the electron would not tend to the ground state. Although, these fluctuations do exist, so my point is moot for all intents and purposes. Although it is important to remember the rate of these fluctuations determines how quickly these transitions to lower energy states occur.

Hi, animator here.
First, let me say I love your videos: the narration is great, the visual design cute and clear (especially liked the depiction of the "sphere of death" in this video), and the content itself is stellar.
However, this is the first video of yours I've seen that uses 60 fps, and I just wanted to point out that it seems to me you wasted the opportunity to craft some really crisp and fluid motion graphics, since the curves and fundamentals are not really on point. Bouncing balls being the foundation of animation training, seeing your Newton's Cradle here looking strangely stiff was honestly quite the disappointment.
Keep up the great content, but please have your animators work that extra mile. If you're gonna leap into 60 fps, you got your work cut out for you, but doing motion graphics should alleviate that, and you did claim the videos take "hundreds of hours", so please spend some of those hours polishing the curves.

Kind regards,
a concerned viewer and unreasonable perfectionist.

есть у этой теории один здоровый минус: энергия которая, высвобождается при переходе на более низкий уровень не может просто исчезнуть. это противоречит закону сохранения энергии (тепло от сгоревшей ветки не пропадает, чтото обязательно нагревается). эта энергия передается другим объектам которые в свою очередь переходят, получив энергию на более высокие состояния. как результат: теория -- неверна.
there is one "big minus" in this theory: the energy that is released during the transition to a lower level can not just disappear. it is contrary to the law of conservation of energy (heat from burnt branches is not lost, something definitely is heated). Actually, this method is incapable of destroying the entire universe. The bubble surrounding the vacuum decay expands only at the speed of light; the universe, however, is expanding at a rate much faster than that. The vacuum decay would be capable of only destroying the (relatively) small part of the universe that lies within its cosmic event horizon. The rest of the universe would never be touched by it. Our current cosmic event horizon lies about 16 billion light years away, so, if the vacuum decay event occurred beyond that, we would never know about it--even if we waited an infinite amount of time!

The end of all things as we know it?

I suppose the easy ones have been covered like stuff smashing into the Earth, us blowing ourselves up, or some virus/bacteria wiping out all humans...

Have self-replicating robots (nano or even 'normal' sized) been covered? As they would consume all the resources and effectively squeeze out biological life.

There's also the possibility of the Earth being flung out of the solar system by some random object flying near or through our space, or even it being done deliberately to escape an exploding sun; course the latter means trying to save the planet as opposed to it's end.

Perhaps more.. topical? Is the displacement of humanity that will likely happen over the next 100-1000 years as sea levels rise dramatically. Not quite doomsday, but having various coastal cities underwater would seem like it. So many connected events that could happen from all that water and ice shifting from it's current locations in such a short period of time.

I suppose there's also the philosophical 'doomsday' scenarios of all of existence is a computer program, or we are all the result of a dream of some individual; and all will be gone if the program ever stops or the person wakes up.
